data.title: 1. The work by Alekseevsky, 1888
data.text:
Alekseevsky’s work On functions similar to the gamma function was published in Communications of Kharkov mathematical society in two papers [Ale1888], [Ale1889], 1888-1889.

1.1. The function G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥G(x)italic_G ( italic_x ). The article by Alekseevsky begins with the words: The first problem, whose solution is the topic of the present investigation, is to investigate properties of a function G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥G(x)italic_G ( italic_x ) satisfying the equation:

(1.1) G⁢(x+1)=Γ⁢(x)⁢G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥1Γ𝑥𝐺𝑥G(x+1)=\Gamma(x)\,G(x)italic_G ( italic_x + 1 ) = roman_Γ ( italic_x ) italic_G ( italic_x )

under the condition

(1.2) G⁢(1)=1.𝐺11G(1)=1.italic_G ( 1 ) = 1 .

Here there are no references, no names, no motivations, no acknowledgements. It is hard to believe that the author simply decided to attack such an exotic problem and successfully solved it. Actually, the exposition in the article was backwards to the real way of thinking; this is discussed below in Subsect. 1.

We pass to logarithms in (1.1) and come to the difference equation

ln⁡G⁢(x+1)−ln⁡G⁢(x)=ln⁡Γ⁢(x).𝐺𝑥1𝐺𝑥Γ𝑥\ln G(x+1)-\ln G(x)=\ln\Gamma(x).roman_ln italic_G ( italic_x + 1 ) - roman_ln italic_G ( italic_x ) = roman_ln roman_Γ ( italic_x ) .

Clearly, a solution of the functional equation (1.2) is determined up to a periodic factor. Further results show that it is a ‘correct’ solution in an informal sense.

In §5, using the integral representation (1.4), he gets a decomposition of G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥G(x)italic_G ( italic_x ) into a Weierstrass product:

where

is the Euler constant (cf. the similar expression for Γ⁢(x)Γ𝑥\Gamma(x)roman_Γ ( italic_x ) in [Erd1953], 1.1 (3)). Next, he noticed that this formula gives an expression for G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥G(x)italic_G ( italic_x ) on the whole complex plane.

In §2, Alekseevsky gets a counterpart of the Euler definition of the gamma function, cf. [Erd1953], 1.1 (2),

Looking to the formula in Appell’s paper, Alekseevsky understood that it is possible to manipulate with Weierstrass-type product over a quadrant in the lattice ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}blackboard_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Certainly, Alekseevsky kept in mind the multiple gamma function with several parameters. The introductory part of dissertation [Ale1892] contains the following ’thesis’:

This ’thesis’ had no continuation in the text of the dissertation.

Visiting Leipzig in 1894, Alekseevsky published a short paper [Ale1894] in German in Leipz. Ber. (communicated by Sophus Lie), and, apparently, his work became known due to this publication. The paper is a sketch of [Ale1888]-[Ale1889] with some additional clams at the end of the paper. In particular,

Daher folgt:

(1) Functionen sind construirt aus einer Function H𝐻Hitalic_H, die analog der Function Γnormal-Γ\Gammaroman_Γ ist.

(2) Dieser Satz giebt auch eine ähnliche Beziehung der Modulfunctionen von Hermite zur Function H𝐻Hitalic_H.

(3) Aus der Betrachtung der Functionen höherer Ordnung, die analog der Function Γ⁢(x)normal-Γ𝑥\Gamma(x)roman_Γ ( italic_x ) sind, folgt:

Die Euler’schen Functionen von Herrn Appell sind Producte von Functionen, die analog der Gammafunction sind.

Clearly, in (3) Alekseevsky claims that an Appell function is a product of two multiple gammas .

In any case, the multiple gamma function with several parameters had not appear in published papers of Alekseevsky and actually was introduced by Barnes [Bar1904]. In Subsect. 3, we continue this discussion.

2.2. The double gamma function, 1899-1907. The work of Alekseevsky became known (may be, due to the publication [Ale1894]). After this, the double gamma function was a topic of publications by Ernest Barnes [Bar1899], [Bar1900.1], [Bar1900.2], [Bar1901], [Bar1904], Jean Beaupain [Bea1903], [Bea1904], [Bea1907], Godfrey Hardy [Har1905.1], [Har1905.2], Vladimir Steklov [Ste1904]. The most important result of these works was the introduction of the multiple gamma functions by Barnes [Bar1904].

As it was observed in [Ada2014], this function was mentioned in the second edition [WhWa1912] of E. T. Whittaker, G. N. Watson A course of Modern Analysis (Chapter XII, Examples 48-50, namely (1.6) as a definition, (1.1), (1.5), (1.11)). Next, it was mentioned in the fourth edition [Grad1963] of Gradshteyn, Ryzhik Tables of integrals, sums, and series, lines 6.441, 8.333, with references to Whittaker–Watson.

The double gamma is absent in other handbooks on special functions as Higher transcendental functions [Erd1953], or Prudnikov, Brychkov, Marichev, [PBM1985].

I have seen (mainly, due to [Gus1952]) few additional appearances of such functions in literature. L. Bendersky [Ben1933] published in 1933 big detailed investigation on higher Kinkelin functions (he probably didn’t know about his predecessors). Boris Rimsky-Korsakov published the paper [Rim1947] on multiplication theorems for higher Kinkelin functions , and the paper [Rim1957] about further generalizations of the gamma function.

The double gamma function is discussed in the obituary of Barnes written by Edmund Whittaker [Whi1954].

2.5. A new appearance. The double gamma function came again in the work by Takuro Shintani [Shi1976]-[Shi1977]. After that, the function started showing up in various math problems, we only present few references [Vig1979], [Sar1987], [Var1988], [NiYo2009], [Ada2014], [Ost2013], [AlKu2023], [KarKu2024].

Shintani [Shi1977] also introduced the double sine

Much later (and independently) Ludvig Faddeev [Fad1995] introduced ’quantum dilogarithm, which is very similar to the double sine. However, it appeared in a completely new context, and now the term ’quantum dilogarithm’ is even more common than ’double sine’.

For instance, see nice applications of the double sine in representation-theoretical spirit (which were the reason of my interest to this topic) in [Kash1998], [FoCh1999], [KLS2002]).

2.6. Why was the double gamma forgotten 70 years? I’ll try to speculate on possible causes. One of the reasons is clear, the function was seriously different from special functions, which were considered at that time, and had no immediate applications. In my opinion, there were some accidental reasons.

Firstly, both Alekseevsky (see below) and Barnes (1874-1953), see [Whi1954], left mathematics.

Secondly, this can be partially related to the structure of [Ale1888]-[Ale1889]. The work can seem like a free fantasy, real external relations become clear only at the end of the second paper. Also, q𝑞qitalic_q-hypergeometric functions were almost unknown in Russia until the appearance for interest to representations of classical groups over finite and p𝑝pitalic_p-adic fields in the 1960s.

Thirdly, a meticulous reader can decide that the actual topic of the paper are the functions ln⁡G⁢(x)𝐺𝑥\ln G(x)roman_ln italic_G ( italic_x ), ln⁡Gn⁢(x)subscript𝐺𝑛𝑥\ln G_{n}(x)roman_ln italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), ln⁡G⁢(x;a)𝐺𝑥𝑎\ln G(x;a)roman_ln italic_G ( italic_x ; italic_a ). For instance, in the paper, the double gamma itself (without a logarithm) never appears in the right hand sides of integrals, this contrasts with the behavior of Γ⁢(x)Γ𝑥\Gamma(x)roman_Γ ( italic_x )) (the gamma function is usual in right hand sides of definite integrals, see, e.g. [Grad1963], [PBM1985]; on the other hand an appearance of ln⁡Γ⁢(⋅)Γ⋅\ln\Gamma(\cdot)roman_ln roman_Γ ( ⋅ ) is relatively exotic). Integrals as (1.10), (1.11) are not too impressive and admit other transformations. Only in §22 a reader can understand that products of double gammas can participate in Heine’s theory of q𝑞qitalic_q-hypergeometric functions.

Now there are no reasons for such doubts. Ludvig Faddeev [Fad1995] observed that the double sine is a kernel of a natural integral operator in L2⁢(ℝ)superscript𝐿2ℝL^{2}(\mathbb{R})italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R ) satisfying highly nontrivial identities, see [Fock1997], [Kash1998], [FoCh1999]. See also the work [KLS2002], where a certain spectral measure for quantum groups are expressed as products of the double sines. Recall that products of usual gamma functions appear as spectral densities for differential and difference operators (as far as they admit explicit evaluations), also such products appear as spectral densities for unitary representations of semisimple groups.

See, also a recent work [KarKu2024].

In several papers 1899-1907, there was used the term ’Alexeiewsky function’. The widely used modern term ’Barnes double gamma’ arises to Shintani [Shi1976]–[Shi1977], who found old Barnes works. Alekseevsky, who was mainly the author of one big work [Ale1888], [Ale1889], [Ale1894], [Ale1904], at that time was forgotten, Barnes was well known due to ’Barnes integrals’, which are a fundamental subject and a tool in theory of special functions, see, e.g., [Whi1954], [AAR1999]. Notice also that Barnes type integrals and the convolution formula for the Mellin transform were the main tools for production of tables of integrals of A. P. Prudnikov, Yu. A. Brychkov, O. I. Marichev [PBM1985] (see explanation of the technology in [Mari1978]).

3. Biography of Alekseevsky

As we have seen above, the main work by Alekseevsky was forgotten, he also was forgotten as a mathematician (his name was mentioned in a few Russian special researches on the history of mathematics, [Gus1950], [Gus1952], [Kru1967], [Bakh1967], [Kru1967.1], [Bel2000] ). On the other hand, he left his memory as an effective director (1907-1911) of the Tomsk Technological Institute.

3.1. Historiography. The main sources about Alekseevsky known for me are:

— Obituary written by president (1906-1946) of the Kharkov mathematical society Dmitry Sintsov [Sin1917].

— Review by Steklov and Sintsov [StSi1904] of works of Alekseevsky (apparently written by Steklov) supporting application of Alekseevsky to the position of extra-ordinary professor.

— Dissertation by Victor Gussov [Gus1950] on the history of investigations on the gamma function and Bessel functions and his paper [Gus1952].

— Works based on archive documents about the history of science in Tomsk and on the history of Tomsk Technological Institute, mainly, Nikolay Krulikovsky [Kru1967] and Yulia Granina [Gran2003]. The latter paper contains a lot of biographical information, below we do not try to abstracting it.

3.2. Early biography. Vladimir Petrovich Alekseevsky was born 07(19).04.1858 in Novgorod governorate (‘guberniya’) and baptized in the village Peretënka (near the railway station Okulovka on the line Moscow–St.Petersburg). His father, Petr Osipovich Alekseevsky, was ‘praporshchik’ [≃similar-to-or-equals\simeq≃ warrant officer] of the Corps of transport engineers [Корпус инженеров путей сообщения]. In 1877, Alekseevsky graduated from the gymnasium in Nizhny Novgorod .

3.3. The Kharkov University, 1877-1905. After gymnasium, Alekseevsky entered the Natural Science Department of the Faculty of Physics and Mathematics of the Kharkov University. Two years later, he transferred to Mathematical Department. In 1881, ‘for family reasons’, he left the University . In 1884, he passed examinations without attending lectures and graduated from the university. At that moment he had three published papers [Ale1884.1]-[Ale1884.3] on integrability of certain ordinary differential equations. They were counted as a graduate (‘candidate’) work .

Since 1881, Alekseevsky taught mathematics, mechanics, physics in Kharkov in the real school (until 1891) and in the Second women’s gymnasium (until 1887). In 1887, he received a scholarship to prepare for a professorship (an analog of a postgraduate student). His main work was published in [Ale1888]–[Ale1889] (in fact, it is one paper split in the middle of a sentence). In 1892, this work was presented as a dissertation [Ale1892]. After the defence (21.02.1893), he became a privatdozent in the Kharkov University.

In March 1894 – November 1895 Alekseevsky visited Leipzig, Göttingen, and Paris. At that time, he published the paper [Ale1894] in Leipz. Ber..

After coming back, he decided to leave the university and became a teacher in a gymnasium in the town Starobelsk in Kharkov governorate since ’university …could do nothing to support the scientist it highly estimated’ (a quotation of a rapport of Steklov in [Sin1917], who worked at the Kharkov university in that time). Alekseevsky returned to the university the next year. Starting 1898, he also worked at the Kharkov Technological Institute.

Four pages of the obituary [Sin1917] (and big part of [StSi1904], see, also, the correspondence of Steklov and Lyapunov in [Ste1991]) contain a description of efforts 1896-1904 of several colleagues to transfer Alekseevsky to the position of extraordinary professor. Participants were: Aleksandr Lyapunov, Vladimir Steklov, Matvey Tikhomandritsky (specialist in elliptic functions), Konstantin Andreev, Dmitry Grave, Ludwig Struve (astronomer), Ivan Osipov (chemist). The nature of obstacles is not clear from the published literature. Steklov (letter to Lyapunov, 14.11.1903) characterized this as an ’absurd story’.

From [Sin1917]: Steklov [1902] explains, why V. P.’s doctoral dissertation [≃similar-to-or-equals\simeq≃ habilitation] was delayed – ’he could have compiled from the scientific results a fully satisfactory dissertation’ and expresses his conviction that ‘if V. P. did not take care to acquire formal rights, having at his disposal all the scientific materials, this circumstance can hardly diminish the scientific merits of V. P. Alekseevsky’. ‘But we must say even more. By now, V. P. Alekseevsky has prepared for printing and is already printing an extensive course of differential and integral calculus.…V. P. Alekseevsky’s course is not a template course adapted to the usual programs of higher educational institutions. It is an independent academic work, where, along with pedagogical requirements, it combines a rigorous and modern approach to the study of the subject’ (finally, this book was not published).

After fifth attempt, 12.01.1904 Alekseevsky got the position of acting extraordinary professor in Kharkov. In the next year, he moved to Tomsk for full professorship.

3.4. The multiple gamma function and a lost work. Let us return to the discussion of Subsect. 1. In the review of Alekseevsky works [StSi1904], Steklov and Sintsov wrote:

And at present time, Alekseevsky continues to successfully develop his theory of functions, which he now calls gammamorphic. He came to functions of an even more general type, for which Kinkelin functions [Steklov keeps in mind Gn⁢(x)subscript𝐺𝑛𝑥G_{n}(x)italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )] are limit cases, and which are related to the known Riemann ζ⁢(s)𝜁𝑠\zeta(s)italic_ζ ( italic_s ) and many other functions important in Analysis and its applications.

These recent studies were reported at the meetings of the Kharkov mathematical society in 1902 and 1903. At the present time, part of them is printing in Communications of our society.

We see in [Khar1904] the following titles of talks by Alekseevsky on the Kharkov mathematical society:

15.02.1902. On the Riemann ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ-function of three arguments.

03.12.1902. On the Riemann ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ-function of two arguments.

24.10.1903. Note on the Kinkelin functions.

31.10.1903. To theory of gammamorphic functions.

Clearly, the third talk corresponds to [Ale1904]. Sintsov mentions a disappeared article ‘On Riemann function ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ’.

It seems clear that the topic of these works were the multiple gamma and related ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ-functions of the type ∑m,n⩾0(z+n⁢a+m⁢b)−ssubscript𝑚𝑛0superscript𝑧𝑛𝑎𝑚𝑏𝑠\sum_{m,n\geqslant 0}(z+na+mb)^{-s}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_n ⩾ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z + italic_n italic_a + italic_m italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (something similar to Barnes [Bar1904]).

In any case, Alekseevsky has not published anything on this topic except claims in [Ale1889], [Ale1892], [Ale1894] quoted above .

3.5. The Tomsk Technological Institute, 1905–1916. The institute was founded in 1900 by chemist-technologist Efim Zubashev (about him, see [Gal2004]) and quickly became a center of education and science in Siberia. For instance, among professors of the beginning of the XX century there were Theodor Molien, one of the founders of representation theory of finite groups and theory of associative algebras , and geologist Vladimir Obruchev.

According [Gran2003], Zubashev invited Alekseevsky to Tomsk in 1900 (the first year of work of the Institute). In April 1905, director Zubashev proposed to Alekseevsky the position of acting ordinary professor (full professor) of theoretical mechanics in Tomsk. Alekseevsky agreed and starting 28.11.1905 worked in Tomsk.

The paper [Gran2003] contains a lot of data on educational and administrative activity of Alekseevsky in Tomsk. We mention only a few formal details.

Students of the Tomsk Technological Institute were involved in the tumultuous events of the Russian Revolution 1905-07. Zubashev (who worked under pressure from both progressives and conservators) was accused of being loyal to the striking students and was exiled from Tomsk. Later, he returned to the director position but had to leave it ‘for health reasons’ (November 1907). The institute council elected Alekseevsky as the new director.

At the end of 1910 – 1911, in Russia there was a wave of student and professor protests against the reform of education initiated by the minister Lev Kasso. These protests involved the Institute. Several professors have been dismissed for oppositionism. Aleksevsky and the institute council tried to reinstate them. As a result, by the highest order, Alekseevsky left the director post (8.06.1911). However, he continued his full professorship.

In 1916 he stubbed his toe, didn’t treat it, and died of gangrene on 13 May.

3.6. Publications of Alekseevsky. The list of scientific publications is contained in our bibliography, [Ale1888]–[Ale1904] (all of them belong to the Kharkov period of his work).

Russian library catalogues show several editions of his lecture courses and problem books (in the Kharkov Technological Institute and in the Tomsk Technological Institute):
